==Japanese==

===Etymology 1===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=o|みつ|k1=みっ|かん}}
Probably from {{etyl|ltc|ja|sort=みかん}} compound {{m|zh|蜜柑|tr=}}. Compare modern {{etyl|cmn|-}} reading ''mìgān''.

Obsolete reading.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=goon|みっかん}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|みっかん}}

# {{lb|ja|sort=みっかん|obsolete}} a [[mandarin orange]], ''[[Citrus unshiu]]'' (fruit)
# {{lb|ja|sort=みっかん|obsolete}} [[citrus]] [[fruit]] in general

===Etymology 2===
{{ja-kanjitab|yomi=irr|sort=みかん}}
{{IPAchar|/mikkan/}} → {{IPAchar|/mikan/}}

Shift in pronunciation from ''mikkan'' above. This change occurred sometime after the 1603 publication of the {{etyl|ja|-}}-{{etyl|pt|-}} ''Nippo Jisho''<ref name="NPJ">'''1603''', {{lang|ja|日葡辞書}} (''[[w:Nippo Jisho|Nippo Jisho]]''): ''{{lang|pt|Vocabulario da Lingoa de Iapam}}'' (in Portuguese), [[w:Nagasaki|Nagasaki]]: [[w:Society of Jesus|Society of Jesus]]</ref>, which still lists the reading as ''mikkan''.

====Pronunciation====
{{ja-pron|yomi=irr|みかん|acc=1|acc_ref=DJR,NHK}}

====Noun====
{{ja-noun|みかん|ミカン}}

# a [[mandarin orange]], ''[[Citrus unshiu]]'' (fruit)
# [[citrus]] [[fruit]] in general

=====Usage notes=====
{{U:ja:biology|ミカン}}
